01.text: The scene shifts to events that occurred some time after events of the previous chapter. Here Jesus responds to the criticisms of the Pharisees. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

01.ref: Why do your disciples violate the traditions of the elders?
01.text: The Pharisees and scribes use this question to criticize Jesus and his disciples. AT: "Your disciples do not respect the rules that our ancestors have given us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is not the same as the law of Moses. This refers to later teachings and interpretations of the law given by religious leaders after Moses.

01.ref: they do not wash their hands
01.text: This washing is not only to clean hands. This refers to a ceremonial washing according to the tradition of the elders. AT: "they do not wash their hands properly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

01.ref: Then why do you violate the commandment of God for the sake of your traditions?
01.text: Jesus answers with a question to criticize what the religious leaders do. AT: "And I see that you refuse to obey God's commands just so that you can follow what your ancestors taught you!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

04.text: Jesus continues to respond to the Pharisees.
In verse 4, Jesus quotes twice from Exodus to show how God expects people to treat their parents.

04.ref: But you say, 'Whoever says to his father or mother "Whatever help you would have received from me is now a gift given to God,"' that person does not need to honor his father
04.text: This has a quotation within a quotation. If necessary you can translate them as indirect quotations. AT: "But you teach that a person does not need to honor his parents by giving them something that may help them if the person tells his parents that he has already given it as a gift to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Here "you" is plural and refers to the Pharisees and scribes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

04.ref: does not need to honor his father
04.text: It is implied that "his father" means "his parents." This means the religious leaders taught that a person does not need to show respect to his parents by taking care of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

04.ref: you have made void the word of God for the sake of your traditions
04.text: "you have made your traditions more important than God's commands"

07.text: Jesus concludes his response to the Pharisees and scribes.
In verses 8 and 9, Jesus quotes the prophet Isaiah to rebuke the Pharisees and scribes.

07.ref: Well did Isaiah prophesy about you
07.text: "Isaiah told the truth in this prophecy about you"
It is implied that Isaiah is speaking what God told him. AT: "when he told what God said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

07.ref: This people honors me with their lips
07.text: Here "lips" refers to speaking. AT: "These people say all the right things to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
All occurrences of this word refer to God.

07.ref: but their heart is far from me
07.text: Here "heart" refers to a person's thoughts or emotions. This phrase is a way of saying the people are not truly devoted to God. AT: "but they do not really love me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Their worship means nothing to me" or "They only pretend to worship me"

10.text: Jesus begins to teach the crowd and his disciples about what defiles a person and why the Pharisees and scribes were wrong to criticize him.

Jesus is emphasizing the importance of what he is about to say. The implied information can  be made explicit. AT: "Listen carefully to what I say so that you may understand its meaning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

10.ref: enters into the mouth ... comes out of the mouth
10.text: Jesus is contrasting what a person eats to what a person says. Jesus means that God is concerned with what a person says rather than what a person eats. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

12.ref: the Pharisees were offended when they heard this statement
12.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "this statement made the Pharisees angry" or "this statement offended the Pharisees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

12.ref: Every plant that my heavenly Father has not planted will be rooted up
12.text: This is a metaphor. Jesus means that the Pharisees do not actually belong to God, so God will remove them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is an important title for God that describes the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "my Father will uproot them" or "my Father will take them out of the ground" or "my Father will remove them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "​them"​ refers to the Pharisees.

12.ref: blind guides ... both will fall into a pit
12.text: Jesus uses another metaphor to describe the Pharisees. Jesus means that the Pharisees do not understand God's commands or how to please him. Therefore, they cannot teach others how to please God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

15.text: Jesus explains the parable that he told in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:15:12|15:13-14]].

15.ref: Are you also still without understanding?
15.text: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the disciples for not understanding the parable. Also, the word "you" is emphasized. Jesus cannot believe his own disciples do not understand. AT: "I am disappointed that you, my disciples, still do not understand what I teach!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

15.ref: Do you not see ... into the latrine?
15.text: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the disciples for not understanding the parable. AT: "Surely you understand ... into the latrine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This a polite term for the place where people bury body waste.

18.text: Jesus continues to explain the parable that he told in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:15:12|15:13-14]].

18.ref: things that come out of the mouth
18.text: This refers to what a person says. AT: "words that a person says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "heart" refers to a person's mind or innermost being. AT: "from inside the person" or "from a person's mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
to say something about another person that is offensive and that is not true
This means a person has not ceremonially washed his hands according to the traditions of the elders.

21.text: This begins an account of Jesus healing the daughter of a Canaanite woman.
It is implied that the disciples went with Jesus. AT: "Jesus and his disciples went away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. AT: "there was a Canaanite woman who came"

21.ref: a Canaanite woman came out from that region
21.text: "a woman from the group of people called Canaanites who live in that region" (UDB). The country of Canaan no longer existed by this time. She was a part of a people group that lived near the cities of Tyre and Sidon.
This phrase implies that she is requesting that Jesus heal her daughter. AT: "Have mercy and heal my daughter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Jesus was not David's literal son, so this may be translated as "Descendant of David" (UDB). However, "Son of David" is also a title for the Messiah, and the woman may have been calling Jesus by this title.

21.ref: my daughter is severely tormented by a demon
21.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "a demon is tormenting my daughter very much" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "word" refers to what a person says. AT: "said nothing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

24.ref: I was not sent to anyone
24.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God did not send me to anyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

24.ref: to the lost sheep of the house of Israel
24.text: This is a metaphor comparing the entire nation of Israel to sheep who have strayed from their shepherd. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:10:05|10:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This shows that the woman is humbling herself before Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

24.ref: It is not right to take the children's bread and throw it to the little dogs
24.text: Jesus responds to the woman with a proverb. The basic meaning is that it is not right to take what is supposed to belong to Jews and give it to non-Jews. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])
Use words here for dogs of any size that people keep as pets.
Here "bread" refers to food in general. AT: "the children's food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The Jews considered dogs to be unclean animals. Here they are used as an image for non-Jews.

27.ref: even the little dogs eat some of the crumbs that fall from their masters' tables
27.text: The woman responds by using the same imagery as Jesus used in the proverb he just spoke. She means non-Jews should be able to have a small amount of the good things Jews are throwing away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Use words here for dogs of any size that people keep as pets. Translate this is you did in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:15:24|15:26]].
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus healed her daughter" or "her daughter became well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an idiom. AT: "at exactly the same time" or "immediately" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

29.text: These verses give background information about the miracle that Jesus is about to perform by feeding four thousand people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]]).

29.ref: lame, blind, mute, and crippled people
29.text: "those who could not walk, those who could not see, those who could not talk, and those whose arms or legs did not function"

29.ref: They presented them at Jesus' feet
29.text: Here "feet" means they placed the sick in front of Jesus. AT: "The crowds brought the sick people to Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the crippled become well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

29.ref: the crippled ... the lame ... the blind
29.text: These nominal adjectives can be stated as adjectives. AT: "the crippled persons ... the lame persons ... the blind persons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

32.text: This begins the account of Jesus feeding four thousand people with seven loaves of bread and a few small fish.

32.ref: or they may faint on the way
32.text: "because they might faint on the way"

32.ref: Where can we get enough loaves of bread in such a deserted place to satisfy so large a crowd?
32.text: The disciples use a question to state that there is nowhere to get food for the crowd. AT: "There is nowhere nearby that we can get enough bread for such a large crowd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

32.ref: Seven, and a few small fish
32.text: The understood information can be made clear. AT: "Seven loaves of bread, and a few small fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Use your language's word for how people customarily eat when there is no table, whether sitting or lying down.

36.text: "Jesus held in his hands." He did not steal them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
